author: sky.cactus
content:
> If we just want a simple change, I still think fee -> price (except for maybe miner premium) is the way to go
<@552133098075193354> Why premium instead of price for one out of three?  It feels like the inconsistency is going to lead to confusion rather than clarity.

author: timbeiko
content: No super strong reason aside that the miner price/premium isn't really quoted the same way. base/network price is the network giving you a quote, max price is you giving a quote to the network, and "miner price" reads as though the miner gives you a quote while it is the opposite. I guess "premium" could be implemented that way?

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, I see.

author: sky.cactus
content: I hadn't thought about the direction really previously.

author: sky.cactus
content: It makes more sense why people liked "tip" in that case (though I still prefer bribe over tip).

author: timbeiko
content: I'm very against "bribe" üòõ It feels like a loaded terms w.r.t. miners, and I don't think there's any upside to doing that. I think I'm personally more and more comfortable with `budget`, `inclusion premium` and `network price` even though they aren't as good "variable names", just because they will make explaining 1559 easier to people.

author: sky.cactus
content: The reason I like bribe is because functionally it is very similar to a bribe in that you propose a price, and the miner will then tell you yes and do what you ask or no and not do what you ask.

author: sky.cactus
content: With a tip, the person will give you service regardless of what you tip and the tip is just "a nice bonus".

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think there is any other word that expresses that dynamic of the buyer getting a one-shot price suggestion and the seller responds with a binary yes/no.

author: sky.cactus
content: Re: Price: Auctions use the term "price" I believe, even though it is the buyer that is proposing the number and the seller that then accepts.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe `miner auction`?

author: sky.cactus
content: `miner bid`?

author: sky.cactus
content: `miner bid price`?

author: ankur2534
content:
> * only *send* transactions to peers where `fee_cap >= head_block.base_fee`
> * only *accept* transactions from peers where `fee_cap >= head_block.base_fee * 0.75`
> * *disconnect* any peer that sends you a transaction where `fee_cap <= head_block.base_fee * 0.5`
> * *evict* any transactions where `fee_cap <= head_block.base_fee * 0.5`
<@!301186049323958275> Why not leave this up to the node operator? Thats what clients do today. E.g. i could run OE today with min-gas-price of 1 gwei, which would allow someone to gasbump ~30-40 times before that tx would ever be included in a block based on current gas prices

author: ankur2534
content: or are you referring to defaults specifically

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!474322772806467600> It is up to the node operator.  However, we get some really nice properties if *most* clients behave similarly.

author: sky.cactus
content: What we program into the clients is what *most* nodes will run, so we would prefer to choose defaults that are healthy and friendly to users.

author: sky.cactus
content: None of this is anything we can enforce.

author: ankur2534
content: I would think * only send transactions to peers where fee_cap >= head_block.base_fee * - wouldn't we want some buffer here in case users anticipate base_fee to decline and so send a tx with slightly lower fee_cap? E.g. * 0.9

author: ankur2534
content: If we're too strict with these cutoffs, we may actually cause larger swings in base_fee than there would be otherwise. E.g. if base fee is dropping and there aren't more txs propagated in the mempool to take advantage of that, it would cause base_fee to continue droping

author: sky.cactus
content: We *don't* want people using the network as their own personal storage space.

author: sky.cactus
content: You do make a good point about the base price swinging a lot though.  ü§î

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, the *idea* is that people should always be submitting transactions that *can* be mined.

author: ankur2534
content: ideally there is a healthy market of txs with fee_cap below the basefee

author: ankur2534
content: thats what causes the negative feedback loop with base_fee - as base_fee drops, there are more txs. as base_fee rises, there are fewer txs

author: ankur2534
content: i agree with the edge case where tx fee_cap < < < base_fee

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not actually sure if we would prefer more swinging, and semi-enforce the idea that "the pending pool isn't your personal storage queue", or if we would rather have less swinging, but meaning people can use the global pending queue as personal storage.

author: sky.cactus
content: Keep in mind, the pending queue is storage with a replication factor of thousands, so it is incredibly expensive (in aggregate) to keep stuff in there.

author: sky.cactus
content: Really, you should submit your low-fee transaction to your own node, and then your node (and only your node) will hold on to it until the base fee drops below the fee cap.  As soon as that happens it will broadcast.

author: sky.cactus
content: We shouldn't, I don't think, be broadcasting that transaction to the entire network until it is *possible* to include it.

author: ankur2534
content: surely theres a gray area: base_fee * 0.9x or 0.8x where the network benefits by having txs ready to be included if/when the base fee drops

author: sky.cactus
content: Keep in mind, that base fee == fee cap likely isn't eligible for inclusion since the miner fee will be 0 in that case.

author: sky.cactus
content: So there is already *some* built-in buffer there.

author: ankur2534
content: creating a system where base_fee is designed to fluctuate *more* seems counter to the intended goal of 1559 to have a more consistent fee market

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think a consistent fee is a goal of 1559.

author: sky.cactus
content: We want users to be able to reliably be included or not without them having to guess at future space demand.

author: ankur2534
content: not consistent fee, but consistent fee market. where someone can expect their txs to be included without having to reason as much about optimizing fees, etc

author: sky.cactus
content: Right, and you can still do that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Set your fee cap to the max you are willing to pay and you are done.

author: sky.cactus
content: The question is whether we should propagate past the first node or not when the user has decided that the current fee is too high.

author: ankur2534
content: and if someone has low time preference - how do they use this system?

author: sky.cactus
content: You can still submit a transaction to a node over JSON-RPC.

author: sky.cactus
content: It just will sit on that node alone until the base fee drops.

author: sky.cactus
content: So the network doesn't have 10,000 copies of your transaction that will mine sometime this week, instead it has one copy of it that is "local" to the user.

author: sky.cactus
content: In an ideal world, the global pending queue is empty most of the time, rather than as it is now which is permanently full.
